OVERVIEW: The Tuque series consists of shallow, well drained, very slowly permeable soils on ridge tops, summits and side slopes of the limestone hills of the Semiarid Mountains and Valleys MLRA.  They formed in material that weathered from limestone bedrock.  Near the type location, the mean annual temperature is about 79 degrees F., and the mean annual precipitation is about 28 inches.  Slopes range from 12 to 60 percent.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS:  Clayey, carbonatic, isohyperthermic Calcic Lithic Petrocalcids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Tuque gravelly clay--wildlife habitat area (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise indicated).
A--0 to 5 inches; dark reddish brown (2.5YR 3/4) gravelly clay; weak fine granular structure; friable; slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many fine and medium roots; about 30 percent, by volume, limestone pebbles; many shell fragments; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary. (4 to 6 inches thick)
Bw--5 to 11 inches; dark red (2.5YR 3/6) gravelly clay; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine granular; firm; slightly sticky, slightly plastic; about 30 percent, by volume, limestone pebbles; moderately alkaline; violently effervescent; clear wavy boundary. (4 to 8 inches thick)
Bkm--11 to 19 inches; very pale brown (10YR 8/3) indurated petrocalcic material with brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) stratified layers; massive; extremely hard, extremely firm, brittle; moderately alkaline; violently effervescent; gradual wavy boundary. (4 to 8 inches thick)
C--19 to 24 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) gravelly clay; massive; firm; slightly sticky, slightly plastic; about 30 percent, by volume, limestone pebbles; moderately alkaline; violently effervescent; gradual wavy boundary. (0 to 8 inches thick)
Cr--24 to 60+ inches; soft limestone bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Ponce, Puerto Rico. Approximately 0.7 mile southwest of El Tuque community from the intersection of P.R. Hwy. 2 and P.R. Hwy. 591; about 1,640 feet north of P.R. Hwy. 591 on a wildlife habitat area.  USGS Punta Cucharas topographic quadrangle (1982); lat. 17 degrees 58 minutes 52 seconds N.; long. 66 degrees 40 minutes 23 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to indurated petrocalcic horizon ranges from 8 to 14 inches.  Reaction is slightly alkaline to moderately alkaline throughout.
The A horizon has hue of 2.5YR or 5YR, value of 3, and chroma of 3 or 4.  Content of rock fragments range from 25 to 50 percent, by volume.  Texture is clay in the fine-earth fraction.
The Bw horizon has hue of 2.5YR, value of 3, and chroma of 4 or 6.  Content of rock fragments range less than 35 percent, by volume.  Texture is clay in the fine-earth fraction.
The Bkm horizon is composed of indurated petrocalcic material.  It has hue of 10YR, value of 8, and chroma of 3.  It can not be excavated with hand tools, but is rippable by mechanized equipment.
The C horizon, where present, has hue of 7.5YR to 2.5Y, value of 4 to 6, and chroma of 4 to 6.  Content of rock fragment range from 25 to 50 percent, by volume.  Texture is clay loam or clay in the fine-earth fraction.
The Cr horizon is composed of soft limestone bedrock.  It can be excavated with difficulty with hand tools, and is rippable by mechanized equipment.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no known series in the same family.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Tuque soils are on ridge tops, summits, and side slopes in limestone hills of the Semiarid Mountains and Valleys MLRA of southern Puerto Rico.  Slopes range from 12 to 60 percent.  They formed in material that weathered from limestone bedrock.  The climate is tropical semiarid.  The average annual precipitation ranges from 18 to 38 inches and the average annual temperature ranges from 77 to 81 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Costa (T), Esteli (T), La Covana (T), Pitahaya (T) and Seboruco (T) series.  All of these soils with the exception of La Covana (T) series are on similar positions but do not have a petrocalcic horizon.  La Covana (T) series have a calcic horizon, do not have a paralithic contact below the petrocalcic horizon within a depth of 60 inches, and is in the clayey skeletal family.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; very slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Most areas of Tuque soils are on naturalized pastureland and wildlife habitat.  The vegetation consists of Mezquite and other xerophytic grasses, shrubs and trees.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Ridge tops, summits and side slopes of limestone hills of the semiarid mountains and valleys of southern Puerto Rico.  The series is small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Raleigh, North Carolina.

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Ponce Soil Survey Area, Puerto Rico; 1971.  The name is from El Tuque community, nearby where it was originally recognized.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon:
Mollic epipedon - the zone from 1 to 6 inches (A horizon).
Cambic horizon - the zone from 6 to 12 inches (Bw horizon).
Petrocalcic horizon - the zone from 12 to 20 inches (Bkm horizon).
The classification was updated with the 09/2002 draft from Clayey-skeletal, carbonatic, isohyperthermic Lithic Petrocalcic Calciustolls to Clayey, carbonatic, isohyperthermic Calcic Lithic Petrocalcids.
Tuque soils are in MLRA 271.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.

HORIZONS.narrative: A--0 to 5 inches; dark reddish brown (2.5YR 3/4) gravelly clay; weak fine granular structure; friable; slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many fine and medium roots; about 30 percent, by volume, limestone pebbles; many shell fragments; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary. (4 to 6 inches thick)

(4 to 8 inches thick)
